channel.title: Change the port of my server on the status page
channel.description: Well is there a way that I can change the port of my server from 43594 to 45000 on the status page ?

item.title: Change the port of my server on the status page
item.dc:creator: @IamGretar IamGretar
item.description:
@IamGretar wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:4, topic:446883”][quote author=IamGretar link=topic=549763.msg4031745#msg4031745 date=1340844375]
Thanks for replying but I was not talking about that. Now I have 2 worlds and Moparscape Server Status Page thinks that the server on 43594 is offline so I would like to change it to 45000.
[/quote]

You could host a dummy server on 43594 so the server status page thinks it’s online.

I don’t think Moparisthebest changes the IP’s or ports of any servers.[/quote]

I’m hosting a server with 2 worlds one on 43594 and one on 45000.

And it somehow looks like there is a broken connection.

Read full topic
item.source: Change the port of my server on the status page

item.title: Change the port of my server on the status page
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

IamGretar:

Thanks for replying but I was not talking about that. Now I have 2 worlds and Moparscape Server Status Page thinks that the server on 43594 is offline so I would like to change it to 45000.

You could host a dummy server on 43594 so the server status page thinks it’s online.

I don’t think Moparisthebest changes the IP’s or ports of any servers.

Read full topic

item.title: Change the port of my server on the status page
item.dc:creator: @Doobage Doobage
item.description:
@Doobage wrote:

IamGretar:

Well is there a way that I can change the port of my server from 43594 to 45000 on the status page ?

Check the image code you put on your webpage, for instance if your iamge says like blahblachblahblah.jpg43594

change the Port number to that.

if not, here is a code but your going to have to upload two pictures showing Online and Offline to your webhost:

<div style="position: absolute; width: 100px; height: 100px; z-index: 1" id="layer1">
 <? 
$ip = "YOURSERVERIP"; 
$port = "45000"; 
if (! $sock = @fsockopen($ip, $port, $num, $error, 5)) 
echo '<img src="http://(your website here)/(directory here)/dead.jpg">'; 
else{ 
echo '<img src="http://(your website here)/(directory here)/alive.jpg">'; 
fclose($sock); 
} 
?></div>

(note this only checks if the port is open on your router so it may not work as intended.)

Read full topic
